header.title: Conjuring Spirits: A Manual of Goetic and Enochian Sorcery

central_thesis: The book presents a modernized, practical, and demystified approach to Goetic and Enochian spirit evocation, asserting that these systems can be effectively practiced by contemporary magicians without archaic biases, focusing on achievable results and the development of self-awareness. It advocates for understanding spirits as potentially external entities or projections of the unconscious mind.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces sorcery as a core discipline of magickal practice, distinguishing it from mere thaumaturgy. It argues for the practical utility of sorcery in achieving desired outcomes and highlights the need for a modern, stripped-down approach to traditional grimoires. The author introduces the concept of Goetic spirits as potentially internal (aspects of consciousness) or external entities and sets the stage for a simplified, effective method of evocation.

This section provides a comprehensive guide to Goetic evocation. It outlines different theories of Goetic spirits, the purpose of evocation (wealth, information, self-control), and the critical roles of the 'Conjurer' and 'Seer.' It details the construction and purpose of the 'Goetic Temple' components (Circle, Triangle, Sigil, Skrying Medium) and a five-part operational sequence: Opening, Conjuration, Reception, Charge, and Dismissal. The section also covers methods for dealing with uncooperative spirits, including curses and punishments, and the importance of a 'Goetic Journal' for tracking progress and development.

This part delves into a revised Enochian Watchtower system, contextualizing its origins in John Dee and Edward Kelly's work. The author critiques the original system's Christian biases and lack of logical symmetry, presenting a redeveloped, gender-neutral, and atheistic version. It outlines the hierarchy of Watchtower entities (Elders, Kings, Seniors, Wardens, Masters, Children), their elemental attributions, and provides Enochian translations. Practical application includes the 'Watchtower Evocation' and a step-by-step 'Watchtower Pentagram Ritual (WPR)' for invoking Watchtower entities, focusing on proper vibration of names and mental visualization.

This concluding section serves as a practical workbook, offering blank pages for the practitioner to record their personal conjurations, operations, and curses. It includes templated rituals for 'Charging the Sigil,' 'The Invocation of the Holy Guardian Angel,' 'The Conjuration' (Goetic), 'The Reception,' 'The Oath,' 'The Dismissal,' and 'The Enochian Conjuration,' providing structured frameworks for magical workings described in the preceding chapters.

key_concepts.definition: The practical method of calling forth spirits from the Goetia (Lesser Key of Solomon) for various purposes, including obtaining information, wealth, love, or exercising self-control. Snuffin frames it as a 'truly practical art' that can involve either external entities or aspects of the magician's unconscious.

A redeveloped Enochian magical system, adapted by Snuffin from Dr. John Dee's original. It aims to remove archaic Christian symbolism and inherent sexism, streamlining the hierarchy of Watchtower entities (Elders, Kings, Seniors, Wardens, Masters, Children) and their elemental attributions for practical and effective evocation within a modern magical paradigm.

The ceremonial space and components required for Goetic operations, consisting of four essential elements: The Circle (for protection), The Triangle (to confine the spirit), The Sigil (to establish a link with the spirit), and a Skrying Medium (for communication).

The two primary roles in a standard Goetic evocation. The 'Conjurer' is responsible for calling up, binding, and interrogating the spirit, while the 'Seer' receives information from the spirit, often through skrying into a mirror or crystal, and relays it to the Conjurer.

A magical seal or symbol representing a spirit. It is central to Goetic work, serving as a focal point to establish a link with the spirit and to charge it with the magician's will. An activated sigil is 'astral-linked to the spirit itself' and is used to protect against the spirit's malice.

Two distinct methods of evocation. 'Astral Evocation' involves contacting the spirit on the astral plane through a Seer, while 'Physical Evocation' aims for a visible manifestation of the spirit in the physical plane, typically within the Triangle, often requiring incense or smoke.

practical_system.description: The practical system integrates Goetic evocation with a revised Enochian Watchtower system, providing a comprehensive manual for spirit work. It emphasizes clear, simple operations with a focus on achievable outcomes. The Goetic component involves setting up a 'temple' (Circle, Triangle, Sigil, Skrying medium) and performing a five-stage evocation. The Enochian component uses a redeveloped Watchtower hierarchy and specific rituals, like the Watchtower Pentagram Ritual (WPR), to evoke entities associated with elemental and planetary forces. The book encourages the use of a 'Grimoire' for personal record-keeping and adaptation of rituals.

relevant_quotes.text: Sorcery, defined here as the art of conjuring spirits, is one of the traditional, core disciplines of magickal practice. It shows up in all magick-using cultures and even in those that suppress most magick, like Christianity.

If you believe that Goetic spirits are parts of your individual consciousness (as do I), then bringing these unruly spirits under control results in greater control of your own consciousness. This purging and perfection of the mind is a key element of the Great Work.

The standard Goetic evocation requires two operators: the Conjurer and the Seer. The Conjurer is responsible for calling up, binding and interrogating the spirit, while the Seer receives information from the spirit and relays it to the Conjurer. A good Conjurer and Seer team can effectively perform any evocation with confidence and skill.

The original Enochian system is very powerful, but it also has many flaws. The information was received and interpreted with an archaic Christian symbolism and nomenclature, an element of Dr. Deeâ€™s personal paradigm that is not an integral part of the Enochian system.

The Watchtower system is a redevelopment of the two traditional Enochian documents into a complete and workable system of evocation. The Christian paradigm has been replaced with one suggested by the Enochian entities themselves, a paradigm revealed to Dee & Kelly as well to me: that of a great city that represents the terrestrial universe.
I dismiss you, O spirit N. Go back unto your errands and habitations, and shall I call on thee again, be thou quick to respond. Go!

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant for contemporary practitioners of Western Esotericism by offering a streamlined and demystified approach to Goetic and Enochian magic. It addresses common criticisms of traditional grimoires by stripping away archaic language and Christian biases, making the systems more accessible and effective for modern magicians. Its emphasis on practical results and the dual interpretation of spirits (external or psychological) aligns with current trends in occult thought, particularly Chaos Magic. It provides a valuable updated framework for two foundational systems.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes experienced and novice practitioners of ceremonial magic, students of Western Esotericism, occultists interested in Goetic and Enochian traditions, and individuals seeking a practical, results-oriented magical manual. It is particularly suited for those who appreciate a rationalized approach to magic and are willing to engage with complex systems from a non-dogmatic perspective.
